newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Coles Myer ends two-year profit slide.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Coles Myer ends two-year profit slide.

text.p: Australia's biggest retailer Coles Myer Ltd on Thursday reported a 41 percent surge in half-year earnings, its first profit rise in almost two years.
The result buoyed Coles' once-sinking share price, which firmed despite a weaker market, and follows a two-year nightmare of sliding profits, controversy and tight-fisted consumers.

Coles, which pockets nearly 18 cents in every retail dollar spent in Australia, reported a net profit of A$273.6 million (US$217 million) for half-year ended January 26, against A$194.5 million a year ago.
Before abnormals, net earnings leapt 23 percent to a better-than-expected A$229 million, boosting the shares 13 cents above Wednesday's close to a morning high of A$6.04 before settling back.
"What is important are people's expectations of the turnaround now. I think that's why the stock is where it is, on anticipation of much better margins and profit," a broker said.
Coles also on Thursday gave a bullish forecast for the full year ending July 27, suggesting it expected more double-digit profit growth in the second half of 1996/97.

"We expect similar percentage growth in second-half profit after tax (excluding property disposal profits and abnormals), subject to market conditions," Coles Myer chief executive Dennis Eck said in a statement.

Coles booked a net abnormal gain of A$44.6 million on the sale of properties and said it had now discarded most of its huge property portfolio. Since 1995, it has sold A$1.1 billion worth of property.
